text:
Our ancestors thought comets were harbingers
of disaster—signs of imminent war, plagues,
death, you name it.

In reality, comet impacts on primordial Earth
may have been the opposite of a death blow:

Comets may have delivered molecules
that helped seed life on our planet.

Comets aren’t exactly the most attractive
celestial objects in the universe—many look

like lumpy potatoes or little space peanuts
or misshapen dumbbells . You’d probably
swipe left on these dusty rocks.

In any case, these space travelers are the
leftovers after the birth of stars and planets,

meaning comets in our solar system are more
than 4 billion years old.

So what on Earth do these space rocks have
to do with the origin of life on, well, Earth?
Here’s the thinking:

While Earth was taking its own sweet time
to cool down from the extreme heat of planetary

formation, millions of comets were cooly racking
up air miles.

These frozen jumbles of rocks, dust, and gas
were scooting around acting like cold storage
for relics of the early solar system.

Comets, being the debris of planetary formation,
may have had the same sort of basic chemicals

that you might find on a nascent planet Earth:
things like methane, carbon monoxide, methanol,
ammonia.

Researchers on Earth have created lab models
of comets and showed that ultraviolet radiation

even in the frigid temperatures of outer space
can transform these basic molecules into more
complex carbon compounds.

Another possibility is that complex carbon
molecules formed at the same time as the solar

system itself—but vaporized close to the
hot cores of planets and stars.

The molecules, however, survived on cooler
comets.
Then bam!

Comets smash into primordial Earth, delivering
our planet the complex carbon molecules required

to kickstart life—components of nucleic
acids, lipids, amino acids, those sorts of

things—just as the planet cooled down enough
to not incinerate them.

Of course for this theory to be true, scientists
would need to have detected complex carbon
molecules on comets.
And guess what?
They have.

Back in 1986 the Giotto mission to Halley’s
Comet took the first snapshot of a comet ever.
Well kind of.

Halley’s Comet probably made a cameo on
this fabulous tapestry from about 1,000 years ago.

But back to Giotto, mass spectrometry along
with infrared data gave astrochemists hints

that there were relatively complex molecules
on the comet.

Scientists weren’t able to identify the
molecules, but many thought Halley’s Comet
was home to polyoxymethylene.

In 2004, NASA’s Stardust mission picked
up some dust around a comet called Wild Two.

Scientists found evidence of the amino acid
glycine, as well as methylamine and ethylamine,
chemicals formed en route to glycine.

And you probably remember the excitement back
in November 2014 when the European Space Agency
landed a probe on comet 67P.

En route to the surface, two instruments on
the Philae lander detected organic molecules

methyl isocyanate, acetone, propanal, and
acetamide, as well as organic polymers, most

likely from the radiation-induced polymerization
of formaldehyde.

Nobody had found these molecules on a comet
before.

The comet also harbors phosphorous, an important
part of the backbone of RNA and DNA, life’s
genetic material.

Although the official mission to 67P is now
over—it made a death dive to the comet’s

surface in late September—scientists still
have tons of data to analyze, so there are

surely chemical goodies—I mean discoveries—to
be made.

As much as I love comets, I should add some
caveats about their possible contributions
to producing me and you.

Even scientists who devote their lives to
comet chemistry think there are probably other

sources of complex carbon molecules important
for seeding life on our planet.

For example, deep sea vents are also likely
candidates for producing complex carbon compounds

needed for life to do its thing, or even start
its thing.

But until we know for sure how the first chemicals
of life appeared on our planet, it’s pretty

awesome to speculate that some of them came
from outer space.

If you have a craving for more comet chemistry,
check out the articles that spawned this video.

In the meantime, thanks for watching and feel
free to subscribe and share.
